title: Cats. 90–93  Four Fragments of Vessels
publication_title: Roman Art at the Art Institute of Chicago
content:
<section class="osci-tk-epub-section body" id="body">Fragment of a Vessel  
1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 3.8 × 4.1 × 0.6 cm (1 1/2 × 1 5/8 × 1/4 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1225

Fragment of a Vessel  
1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 5 × 3.6 × 0.9 cm (2 × 1 7/16 × 3/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1229

Fragment of a Vessel  
1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 2.8 × 6 × 0.3 cm (1 1/8 × 2 3/8 × 1/8 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1208

Fragment of a Vessel  
1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D.  
Roman  
Glass, mosaic glass technique; 3.3 × 2.6 × 0.1 cm (1 5/16 × 1 1/16 × 1/16 in.)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of Theodore W. and Frances S. Robinson, 1949.1211

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">These fragments are a sampling of the mosaic glass vessels with complex designs not represented by complete examples in the Art Institute’s collection. There are numerous mosaic glass fragments in many public and private collections such as the Corning Museum of Glass, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, and the Toledo Museum of Art. The forms vary greatly, from cups and bowls to plates and platters.  
Sidney Goldstein

</section><section id="figures">Four fragments of vessels, all 1st century B.C./mid-1st century A.D., clockwise from top left: cat. 90, cat. 91, cat. 92, cat. 93.

</section>
